commit_message:
Import PublishErrorsHandler from oslo.messaging

log_handler graduated and it's in oslo.messaging now.
Remove unnecessary try/import.

Change-Id: I78cdeba0cb90148b6ebd2f23f1aecb5d1f7ceef8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/34/132934/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: handler = importutils.import_object( "oslo.messaging.notify.log_handler.PublishErrorsHandler", logging.ERROR)
deleted_lines: try: handler = importutils.import_object( "openstack.common.log_handler.PublishErrorsHandler", logging.ERROR) except ImportError: handler = importutils.import_object( "oslo.messaging.notify.log_handler.PublishErrorsHandler", logging.ERROR)

commit_message:
Make _send_sensor_data more cooperative

This change adds yielding execution to other greenthreads to
_send_sensor_data periodic task to make it more cooperative.

Change-Id: I03a54ce272b6899af0a978c27bc787f106a37906
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/84/132884/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: finally: # Yield on every iteration eventlet.sleep(0)

commit_message:
Add openstack_extras and epel dependency

* Required for pacemaker service provider wrappers
  implementation.
* Add Puppet-openstack_extras module which comes to replace
  puppet-openstack in upstream.
  commit sha: b0b83dbf4507db36220f9c04c68e4788109b1c4b
  Source: https://github.com/stackforge/puppet-openstack_extras
* Add a dependency epel module
  v1.0.0 db0cdeba51739e748c965974ec832acada227084
  Source: https://github.com/stahnma/puppet-module-epel

Related blueprint pacemaker-improvements

Change-Id: Ib607cd77d56e55489e2a855c7ca933b8eb9fcaee
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/75/128575/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' shared_context :epel_testing_debuginfo do it do should contain_yumrepo('epel-testing-debuginfo').with({ 'failovermethod' => 'priority', 'proxy' => 'absent', 'enabled' => '0', 'gpgcheck' => '1', }) end end shared_context :epel_testing_debuginfo_6 do include_context :epel_testing_debuginfo it do should contain_yumrepo('epel-testing-debuginfo').with({ 'baseurl' => "http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/testing/6/$basearch/debug", 'gpgkey' => "file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-EPEL-6", 'descr' => "Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux 6 - Testing - $basearch - Debug", }) end end shared_context :epel_testing_debuginfo_5 do include_context :epel_testing_debuginfo it do should contain_yumrepo('epel-testing-debuginfo').with({ 'baseurl' => "http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/testing/5/$basearch/debug", 'gpgkey' => "file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-EPEL-5", 'descr' => "Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux 5 - Testing - $basearch - Debug", }) end end

commit_message:
Add a JSON loader in Angular

    In order to pass data between the server and the client without
breaking Django templating, a directive has been created which loads data from
a script tag with the type application/json. For security reason you must use
the JSONSafeEncoder for dumping the datas into the HTML in order to avoid XSS.

    It provides a json_angular template tag which inject JSON data in a safe
way and use an angular directive to retrieve it in the client.
    Usage is {% json_angular <object_to_dump> <id_of_the_object>%} where the
object will be dumped by horizon.utils.functions.JSONSafeEncoder and the id
could be a string or a value which will be interpolated by the django template
renderer.

Change-Id: Ica3dced5470b66934eaffd68dc85fcac3612c1c9
Implements: blueprint horizon-angular
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/66/73566/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: angular.module('hz.utils.JSONCache', []) .provider('JSONCache', function () { this.$get = ['$cacheFactory', function ($cacheFactory) { return $cacheFactory('JSON'); }]; }) .directive('script', ['JSONCache', '$rootScope', function ($JSONCache, $rootScope) { return { restrict: 'E', terminal: true, compile: function (element, attr) { if (attr.type === 'application/json') { var jsonID = attr.id, // IE is not consistent, in scripts we have to read .text but in // other nodes we have to read .textContent text = element[0].text; $JSONCache.put(jsonID, $rootScope.$eval(text)); } } }; }]); angular.module('hz.utils', ['hz.utils.hzUtils', 'hz.utils.JSONCache']);

commit_message:
New service provider

* Rewrite pacemaker service provider
* Auto-disable basic non-ha service
* Uses p_ prefix if needed
* Look for master to start for multistate resources
* Includes debugging console and specs
* Print debug status on timeout

Related-Blueprint: pacemaker-improvements
Change-Id: I712e52acc5127f02838b88eaf99e6e63a0812897
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/51/129351/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require File.join File.dirname(__FILE__), 'pacemaker.rb' require 'rubygems' require 'pry' class PacemakerConsole include Pacemaker def initialize self.raw_cib_file = 'cib.xml' binding.pry end end PacemakerConsole.new

subject: Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-21 14:51:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/d82a18432153060bf8f5dc3c4e9f384bbea7cdd0', 'message': "Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF

W/o this change, improved pacemaker provider
would not differ OS-aware service pid file from
its own one. That would make impossible to
disable OS-aware services inside pcs provider.

The solution is to separate OS-aware layer from
pacemaker OCF one for pid/run/lock files (we use
only pid files in OCF scripts):

* Unify $OCF_RESKEY_pid_default definitions with
  $HA_RSCTMP and $OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE varaibles
  as well
  (/usr/lib/ocf/lib/heartbeat/ocf-directories::
  ${HA_RSCTMP:=/var/run/resource-agents})

* Add separate pid directories for resources managed
  by pacemaker OCF ($HA_RSCTMP/$OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE/)
  and keep pid files there to distinguish them from
  OS-aware ones.

* While $HA_RSCTMP is owned by root, chown resources'
  subdirectories $OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE to
  $OCF_RESKEY_user to grant daemons
  write access for their pid files as well.

* For start actions of OCF scripts, add safe creation
  and chowning of aforementioned pid directories

* Add missing user/group checks for rabbitmq ocf

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-24 16:48:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/51d503a69e946fbcdf79166e45fd986bc4e38e6b', 'message': "Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF

W/o this change, improved pacemaker provider
would not differ OS-aware service pid file from
its own one. That would make impossible to
disable OS-aware services inside pcs provider.

The solution is to separate OS-aware layer from
pacemaker OCF one for pid/run/lock files (we use
only pid files in OCF scripts):

* Unify $OCF_RESKEY_pid_default definitions with
  $HA_RSCTMP and $OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE varaibles
  as well
  (/usr/lib/ocf/lib/heartbeat/ocf-directories::
  ${HA_RSCTMP:=/var/run/resource-agents})

* Add separate pid directories for resources managed
  by pacemaker OCF ($HA_RSCTMP/$OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE/)
  and keep pid files there to distinguish them from
  OS-aware ones.

* While $HA_RSCTMP is owned by root, chown resources'
  subdirectories $OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE to
  $OCF_RESKEY_user to grant daemons
  write access for their pid files as well.

* For start actions of OCF scripts, add safe creation
  and chowning of aforementioned pid directories

* Add missing user/group checks for rabbitmq ocf

DocImpact
Related blueprint pacemaker-improvements

Change-Id: I7f50e32ced83af8f32fd7907cb5fc723055da121
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-10-29 15:51:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/21b9b81483479188473645326d514602f04c40e0', 'message': 'Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF

W/o this change, improved pacemaker provider
would not differ OS-aware service pid file from
its own one. That would make impossible to
disable OS-aware services inside pcs provider.

The solution is to separate OS-aware layer from
pacemaker OCF one for pid/run/lock files (we use
only pid files in OCF scripts):

* Unify $OCF_RESKEY_pid_default definitions with
  $HA_RSCTMP and "p_$__SCRIPT_NAME" varaibles
  as well
  (/usr/lib/ocf/lib/heartbeat/ocf-directories::
  ${HA_RSCTMP:=/var/run/resource-agents})

* p_ prefix is required due to resources naming
  conventions we use in Fuel

* Add separate pid directories for resources managed
  by pacemaker OCF ($HA_RSCTMP/$__SCRIPT_NAME/)
  and keep pid files there to distinguish them from
  OS-aware ones.

* While $HA_RSCTMP is owned by root, chown resources'
  subdirectories $__SCRIPT_NAME to
  $OCF_RESKEY_user to grant daemons
  write access for their pid files as well.

* For start actions of OCF scripts, add safe creation
  and chowning of aforementioned pid directories

* Add missing user/group checks for rabbitmq ocf

DocImpact
Related blueprint pacemaker-improvements

Change-Id: I7f50e32ced83af8f32fd7907cb5fc723055da121
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-10-30 16:34:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/87f778ae79646bc129c14ad6fb842377b53e9cc7', 'message': 'Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF

W/o this change, improved pacemaker provider
would not differ OS-aware service pid file from
its own one. That would make impossible to
disable OS-aware services inside pcs provider.

The solution is to separate OS-aware layer from
pacemaker OCF one for pid/run/lock files (we use
only pid files in OCF scripts):

* Unify $OCF_RESKEY_pid_default definitions with
  $HA_RSCTMP and "$__SCRIPT_NAME" varaibles
* Add separate pid directories for resources managed
  by pacemaker OCF ($HA_RSCTMP/$__SCRIPT_NAME/)
  and keep pid files there to distinguish them from
  OS-aware ones.
* While $HA_RSCTMP is owned by root, chown resources'
  subdirectories $__SCRIPT_NAME to
  $OCF_RESKEY_user to grant daemons
  write access for their pid files as well.
* For status actions of OCF scripts, add safe creation
  and chowning of aforementioned pid directories
* Add missing user/group checks for rabbitmq ocf
* Add debug for pid file related actoins
* Make empty pidfile checks
* Fix pidfile creation on start action of neutron
  agents and rabbitmq OCF
* Fix pidfile deletion on stop action for mysql OCF
* Add missing pid file checks for rabbitmq status
  and update report not running conditions

DocImpact
Related blueprint pacemaker-improvements

Change-Id: I7f50e32ced83af8f32fd7907cb5fc723055da121
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Use separate pid files for Pacemaker OCF

W/o this change, improved pacemaker provider
would not differ OS-aware service pid file from
its own one. That would make impossible to
disable OS-aware services inside pcs provider.

The solution is to separate OS-aware layer from
pacemaker OCF one for pid/run/lock files (we use
only pid files in OCF scripts):

* Unify $OCF_RESKEY_pid_default definitions with
  $HA_RSCTMP and "$__SCRIPT_NAME" varaibles
* Add separate pid directories for resources managed
  by pacemaker OCF ($HA_RSCTMP/$__SCRIPT_NAME/)
  and keep pid files there to distinguish them from
  OS-aware ones.
* While $HA_RSCTMP is owned by root, chown resources'
  subdirectories $__SCRIPT_NAME to
  $OCF_RESKEY_user to grant daemons
  write access for their pid files as well.
* For status actions of OCF scripts, add safe creation
  and chowning of aforementioned pid directories
* Add missing user/group checks for rabbitmq ocf
* Add debug for pid file related actoins
* Make empty pidfile checks
* Fix pidfile creation on start action of neutron
  agents OCF
* Fix pidfile deletion on stop action for mysql OCF

DocImpact
Related blueprint pacemaker-improvements

Fuel-CI: disable
Change-Id: I7f50e32ced83af8f32fd7907cb5fc723055da121
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/25/129925/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OCF_RESKEY_pid_default="$HA_RSCTMP/$OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE/$OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE.pid" # check and make PID file dir local PID_DIR="$( dirname $OCF_RESKEY_pid )" if [ ! -d "${PID_DIR}" ] ; then mkdir -p "${PID_DIR}" chown -R ${OCF_RESKEY_user} "${PID_DIR}" chmod 755 "${PID_DIR}" fi

commit_message:
Remove old basic service_disables

* Remove *_stopped/*_disabled services definitions
  * RabbitMQ
  * Heat Engine
  * Galera
* Use clear titles for services and use name if service
  name should be changed (e.g from params.pp)
* Fix mangling for corosync services.

Related to blueprint granular-deployment-based-on-tasks

Fuel-CI: disable
Change-Id: Iedd11984f43f0d653526113ac208470aa4f39a94

deleted_lines: # Disable OS-aware service, because rabbitmq-server managed by Pacemaker. service {'rabbitmq-server__disabled': name => 'rabbitmq-server', ensure => 'stopped', enable => false, } Service['rabbitmq-server__disabled'] -> File['rabbitmq-ocf'] -> Service["$service_name"]

commit_message:
Fix WSGI unittests on systems without IPv6

Test test_start_random_port_with_ipv6 and test_app_using_ipv6_and_ssl
fail when IPv6 is either disabled or not available on the system.
This patch skips the test if the wsgi server can't be started due
to ipv6 address assignment error.

Closes-Bug: 1174404
Change-Id: I5ada25ca6ba191a566a45bfba1a6703db09f273e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/08/131308/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: server.start(None, 0, host="::1") except Exception as exc: msg = "IPv6 is not supported: %s" % str(exc) self.skipTest(msg) try: server.start(hello_world, 0, host="::1") except Exception as exc: msg = "IPv6 is not supported: %s" % str(exc) self.skipTest(msg)

design would be very similar to other SAN-type devices from other

Related to blueprint violinmemory-v6000-storage-drivers

Change-Id: I918550782d11cfab72ad7b8951f88a14a8942633

commit_message:
Propose: Add cinder volume drivers for Violin Memory storage arrays

A new set of Cinder drivers are required to support Violin Memory
storage arrays.  Both ISCSI and Fibrechannel should be supported.  The
design would be very similar to other SAN-type devices from other
contributors.

Related to blueprint violinmemory-v6000-storage-drivers

Change-Id: I918550782d11cfab72ad7b8951f88a14a8942633
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/47/130647/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Cinder Volume ISCSI/FCP Drivers for VMEM v6000 Series Arrays ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/violinmemory-v6000-storage-drivers The purpose of this blueprint is to build and contribute drivers for VMEM's V6000 storage arrays. Both iscsi and fcp will be supported. The drivers are relatively straightfoward implementations of the standard storage APIs and will include all Kilo api requirements and tests. On the backend, they will be using a communication library built and maintained by VMEM. The current best-practice AFAIK is to keep these separate and available either from the company's website and/or pyPI, so there are no plans to contribute them. Problem description =================== A new set of Cinder drivers are required to support Violin Memory storage arrays. Both ISCSI and Fibrechannel should be supported. The design would be very similar to other SAN-type devices from other contributors. Borrowing from the nice folks that made the XtremIO driver proposal (specs/juno/xtremio_cinder_volume_driver.rst), this graphic explains the mgmt and data path integration. +----------------+ +--------+---------+ | | Command | | | | Path | Cinder + | | Nova +---------------> | Cinder Volume | | | | | | | | | +-----+----------+ +--------+---------+ | | | | | | | | | | +------------------+ | | | | Command +--+ | Path + | VMEM driver stack| | | | | | | | +------+-----------+ | | | | | + | VMEM 'xg-tools' Rest API | | v | | +----------------+ | +-----------------+ | | | | | | Compute | | | | | | +----> VMEM flash | | | Data Link | array | | +-----------------------------------------+ | +----------------+ +-----------------+ Proposed change =============== From a cloud admin perspective, there would be two new drivers available: * violin.v6000_iscsi.V6000ISCSIDriver * violin.v6000_fcp.V6000FCPDriver As mentioned above, the full required set of volume API functions will be provided in both drivers. Code changes made as part of this blueprint would include: * 3 new driver files * common functions * iscsi protocol support * fcp protocol support * 3 new test files (one for each driver file mentioned above) * 1 fake communcation test module (to Mock out the backend comm) Alternatives ------------ N/A Data model impact ----------------- N/A REST API impact --------------- N/A Security impact --------------- The drivers require that the user provide an admin-level user and password for the VMEM storage array in the cinder.conf file (same as other SAN drivers). Standard password security issues apply. Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ The drivers include the use of the lockutils to enforce serialization of specific groups of calls like luns creation & export and snapshot creation and export. All these requests use a configurable global timeout and retry mechanism so there is no concern about getting perma-locked. Other deployer impact --------------------- Several VMEM-specific configuration flags will be added: * gateway_vip/mga/mgb IP addresses - each Violin array has a two-node cluster running that provides the LUN services for the flash backend. One of the two nodes is designated as 'master' for configuration, and maintains a Virtual IP (vip) for that role. * use_thin_luns/igroups flags - global flags to set default behavior for OpenStack when creating/exporting luns with VMEM drivers. Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Ryan Lucio, rlucio (irc) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Currently the drivers & tests are internally development-complete for Icehouse, and are Juno compatible. * Update drivers/tests for any incoming Kilo requirements or coding stds * Setup/run CI infrastructure (hardware is already installed) * Complete driver certification process * publish array REST-api library 'xg-tools' aka 'vxg' on pyPI Dependencies ============ As mentioned earlier the VMEM drivers will have a dependency on our REST-api library. This library is only officially available to VMEM customers via our support site at the moment. However, I would like to publish them at pyPI and maybe roll a tarball and RPM for them. Testing ======= Unit tests will have good coverage of API functions and common code paths. System testing will be completed for both drivers internally @VMEM. In addition we will need to complete the upstream certification test and will need to setup the required CI service for upstream testing. Documentation Impact ==================== AFAIK we will need to write and submit driver docs for the Admin guide. References ========== N/A

Improve shell cmds and logging in 'delete_vips'

Get rid of piping to 'grep' in 'ip_address_show'
method and fix issues with logging.

Change-Id: Icbfba0fce437001ba9c4c6c07a0811f49654dfd5

commit_message:
create magnum repository

Magnum is a containers service. It will probably not be part of the
compute program (whether or not programs even exist in 6 months). The
team behind this believes they are blocked making progress until they
have access to a gerrit repo.

Change-Id: Ifa1036f84e58140c376f93ce3ef19e192396a9d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/54/133054/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - project: openstack/magnum description: Containers Service for first class support of containers in OpenStack

subject: Fix nova-compute start issue after evacuate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-24 23:58:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d1c35286c99c53d26e6054e9881b86b2d4c4e290', 'message': "Fix nova-compute start issue after evacuate

After evacuated successfully, and restarting the failed
host to get it back, Nova will call init_host() and then
call method _destroy_evacuated_instances(). In method
_destroy_evacuated_instances(), nova will check again if
the storage is shared or not to decide if the storage
should be destroyed. Now nova is using temp file to check
if it's shared file system, but it's wrong for RBD case.
So Nova will attempt to delete the shared block storage,
which will fail since it's used by the new instance. This
patch fixes this issue and adds test cases for that.

Closes-Bug: 1385484

commit_message:
Fix nova-compute start issue after evacuate

After evacuated successfully, and restarting the failed
host to get it back, Nova will call init_host() and then
call method _destroy_evacuated_instances(). In method
_destroy_evacuated_instances(), nova will check again if
the storage is shared or not to decide if the storage
should be destroyed. Now nova is using temp file to check
if it's shared file system, but it's wrong for RBD case.
So Nova will attempt to delete the shared block storage,
which will fail since it's used by the new instance. This
patch fixes this issue and adds test cases for that.

Closes-Bug: 1385484

Change-Id: I71bb818f3c2930b3a2ddf1817dfd4bb61fae7e98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/05/130905/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('os.path.exists') @mock.patch('tempfile.mkstemp') @mock.patch('os.close') def test_check_instance_shared_storage_local(self, mock_close, mock_mkstemp, mock_exists): instance_uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.flags(images_type='raw', group='libvirt') self.flags(instances_path='/tmp') mock_exists.return_value = True mock_mkstemp.return_value = (-1, '/tmp/{0}/file'.format(instance_uuid)) mock_close.return_value = None driver = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) instance = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context) temp_file = driver.check_instance_shared_storage_local(self.context, instance) self.assertEqual('/tmp/{0}/file'.format(instance_uuid), temp_file['filename']) def test_check_instance_shared_storage_local_rbd(self): self.flags(images_type='rbd', group='libvirt') driver = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) instance = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context) self.assertIsNone(driver. check_instance_shared_storage_local(self.context, instance))

commit_message:
Updated from openstack-manuals

Change-Id: Ia7ccb65179fbe5acc9aaf4f4ae77e75837e1edc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ha-guide refs/changes/60/132960/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-11-05 07:13+0000\n" "PO-Revision-Date: 2014-11-06 04:20+0000\n"msgstr "Object Storage のアカウントと関連メタデータを保持し、アカウントサーバーがアクセスする、SQLite データベース。"msgstr "ボタンクラス"msgstr "ボタンクラス"msgstr "Horizon 内で関連するボタン種別のグループ。仮想マシンを起動、停止、休止するボタンは、1 つのクラスにある。Floating IP アドレスを関連付ける、関連付けを解除するボタンは、別のクラスにある。"msgstr "1 つの文字を構成するビットの組。通常は 8 ビットで 1 バイトになる。"msgstr "DoS は、サービス妨害攻撃の省略形である。正当なユーザーがサービスを使用することを妨害するための悪意のある試み。"msgstr "非推奨認証"msgstr "管理者が、Identity を使用する代わりに、<literal>nova-manage</literal> コマンド経由でユーザーを作成および管理できる、Compute 内のオプション。"msgstr "Desktop-as-a-Service"msgstr "デスクトップ環境群を提供するプラットフォーム。ユーザーがどこからでもデスクトップを利用するためにログインする可能性がある。一般的な使用、開発、同種のテスト環境さえも提供できる。"msgstr "Compute RBAC システムにあるデフォルトのロールの 1 つ。新規ユーザーに割り当てられるデフォルトのロール。"msgstr "OpenStack は、Compute 経由で Amazon EC2 API へのアクセスをサポートする。"msgstr "OpenStack が Amazon EC2 を利用できるようにするための Compute のコンポーネント。"msgstr "Compute EC2 API 利用時に EC2 アクセスキーと一緒に使用される。各リクエストを電子署名するために使用される。"msgstr "URL やポート番号のエンドポイントの一覧。Object Storage、Compute、Identity などのサービスがアクセスできる場所を意味する。"msgstr "排他キュー"msgstr "排他キュー"msgstr "認可されたノードに IP アドレスを割り当てる Compute のコンポーネント。DHCP、DNS、ルーティングの設定とサービスが別の何かにより提供されることを仮定している。"msgstr "インスタンスの起動前に、OS のネットワーク設定情報を仮想マシンイメージ内に注入する、Compute のネットワーク方式。"msgstr "リング内でオブジェクトの場所を判断するために、Object Storage により使用される。オブジェクトをパーティションに対応付ける。"msgstr "リサイズ"msgstr "リサイズ"msgstr "既存のサーバーを別のフレーバーに変更する。サーバーをスケールアップまたはスケールダウンする。元のサーバーは、問題発生時にロールバックできるよう保存される。すべてのリサイズは、元のサーバーを削除するときに、テストされ、明示的に確認される必要がある。"msgstr "REST を使用する Web サービス API の 1 種。REST は、WWW 向けに使用される、ハイパーメディアシステム向けのアーキテクチャーの形式である。"msgstr "Identity のサービスカタログで利用可能な各サービスに割り当てられる一意な ID。"msgstr "複数のクライアントにより同時にアクセス可能なブロックストレージ。例えば NFS。"msgstr "クラウドで認証情報を管理するための仕様。現在、OpenStack によりサポートされていない。"msgstr "コア OpenStack API に対して自動テストを実行する。Rails で書かれている。"msgstr "オペレーティングシステムのコマンド経由で、仮想マシンインスタンスが正常に再起動する、制御された再起動。"msgstr "指定されたテンプレート (AWS CloudFormation テンプレートまたは Heat Orchestration Template (HOT)) に基づいて、Orchestration により作成、管理される OpenStack リソース群。"msgstr "Compute AMQP 通信をキャプチャーする、コミュニティーのプロジェクト。デバッグに有用。"

subject: Add ability to compare two verification results
revisions:

commit_message:
Add ability to compare two verification results

Currently there is no built-in way in Rally to see the differences
between two verification runs. This feature adds a compare sub-command
to rally verify that takes two verification IDs as input and output the
differences between two verifications in the desired format, html, csv,
json or pprint. Output may be printed to std out or directed to file
destination specified.

Tasks
- Add compare sub-command to rally verify.
- Add ability to specify output format and file name of comparison
  report.
  Initial support will allow for output to either HTML, pretty print
  or CSV.
- Create rally/verification/verifiers/tempest/diff.py that handles all
  the comparing and output of results.
- Create required mako template (compare.mako) and renderer
  (compare2html.py) class for HTML output.
- Added percentage threshold argument for determining execution time
  differences

Change-Id: I0276e431d7d1ad89b1b28306cd0e0ea7e1174217
Implements: blueprint tempest-compare

commit_message:
Confirm Dialog for Delete operation in Network Topology

When we click a delete button in network topology, the corresponding
delete operation is issued immediately. Now, a confirm dialog is
displayed first to confirm the user's action and then the item gets
deleted accordingly. It brings better consistency with delete
operations of other tables.

Change-Id: I2d6d2aab092d99ab536c84b56fb79a2dac37fd9a
Closes-Bug: #1242251

commit_message:
Add unit tests for iscsi.py

There is no unit test for cinder/volume/targets/iscsi.py.
Here I add some test cases.

Change-Id: I51e625957827e7e7f03c31232094c8993571744b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/90/122090/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from cinder import context from cinder import exception from cinder import test from cinder.volume import configuration as conf from cinder.volume.targets import iscsi class ISCSITargetTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(ISCSITargetTestCase, self).setUp() self.configuration = mock.Mock(spec=conf.Configuration) self.configuration.iscsi_target_prefix = 'iqn.2010-10.org.openstack:' self.configuration.volume_driver = \ 'cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMISCSIDriver' self.configuration.iscsi_helper = 'tgtadm' self.ISCSI = iscsi.ISCSITarget(configuration=self.configuration) self.vol_1 = {'id': '114774fb-e15a-4fae-8ee2-c9723e3645ef', 'size': 1, 'name': 'vol1', 'host': 'hostname@backend', 'os_type': 'linux', 'provider_location': 'loc1 loc2', 'provider_auth': 'provider abc 123', 'encryption_key_id': None} self.vol_2 = {'id': '114774fb-e15a-4fae-8ee2-c9723e3645ef', 'size': 1, 'name': 'vol1', 'host': 'hostname@backend', 'os_type': 'linux', 'provider_location': None, 'provider_auth': 'provider abc 123', 'encryption_key_id': None} def fake_do_iscsi_discovery_none(self, volume): return None def fake_do_iscsi_discovery_not_none(self, volume): return 'loc3 loc4' def test_initialize_connection(self): expected = {'auth_method': 'provider', 'auth_username': 'abc', 'auth_password': '123', 'encrypted': False, 'target_discovered': False, 'target_iqn': 'loc2', 'target_lun': 1, 'target_portal': 'loc1', 'volume_id': '114774fb-e15a-4fae-8ee2-c9723e3645ef'} ret = self.ISCSI.initialize_connection(self.vol_1, **{}) self.assertEqual('iscsi', ret['driver_volume_type']) self.assertEqual(expected, ret['data']) def test_initialize_connection_without_providor_location(self): self.stubs.Set(iscsi.ISCSITarget, '_do_iscsi_discovery', self.fake_do_iscsi_discovery_none) self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidVolume, self.ISCSI.initialize_connection, self.vol_2, **{}) def test_initialize_connection_without_providor_location_2(self): self.stubs.Set(iscsi.ISCSITarget, '_do_iscsi_discovery', self.fake_do_iscsi_discovery_not_none) expected = {'auth_method': 'provider', 'auth_username': 'abc', 'auth_password': '123', 'encrypted': False, 'target_discovered': True, 'target_iqn': 'loc4', 'target_lun': 1, 'target_portal': 'loc3', 'volume_id': '114774fb-e15a-4fae-8ee2-c9723e3645ef'} ret = self.ISCSI.initialize_connection(self.vol_2, **{}) self.assertEqual('iscsi', ret['driver_volume_type']) self.assertEqual(expected, ret['data']) def test_detach_volume(self): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() self.assertIsNone(self.ISCSI.detach_volume(ctxt, self.vol_1)) def test_validate_connector(self): connector = ['initiator'] self.assertIsNone(self.ISCSI.validate_connector(connector)) def test_validate_connector_without_initiator(self): connector = [] self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.ISCSI.validate_connector, connector=connector) def test_iscsi_authentication(self): chap = 'aaa' name = 'bbb' password = 'ccc' expected = chap+' '+name+' '+password self.assertEqual(expected, self.ISCSI._iscsi_authentication(chap, name, password))

commit_message:
Fixed exception handling in test_delete_nonexistent_snapshot

test_delete_nonexistent_snapshot checks the exception at incorrect
part in test code.
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: Id664087ee824e073715627889463f589ee7820c6

commit_message:
Validate nested stacks for resource groups

Currently we don't fail fast, even if there is no
resource type mapping in the nested template
which should fail validation.

This change will to recurse and do static template
validation both for OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup and
OS::Heat::ResourceGroup.

Closes-Bug: #1389104
Change-Id: I7accc3c0f121e238f915a92bbd209b7ec11533a7

subject: Handle os.listdir failures in container-updater
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-03 02:58:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/751a9d42e1ff0c3a568d76f3eaf798b99173f8f6', 'message': 'Handle os.listdir failures in container-updater

While investigating bug 1375348 I discovered the problem
reported there was not limited to the object-auditor.  The
container-updated has similar bugs.

This patch catches the unhandled exception that can be thrown by
os.listdir.  This required instrumenting the get_paths function to
handle exceptions thrown from os.listdir.  The patch also catches
exceptions in the run_forever() function so that we can ensure that
sys.exit() is always called in the child.  Without this change,
we can end up with orphaned processes in the same manner as is
documented in bug 1375348.

Change-Id: I7eed122bf6b663e6e7894ace136b6f4653db4985
Related-bug: 1375348

commit_message:
Handle os.listdir failures in container-updater

While investigating bug 1375348 I discovered the problem
reported there was not limited to the object-auditor.  The
container-updated has similar bugs.

This patch catches the unhandled exception that can be thrown by
os.listdir.

Change-Id: I7eed122bf6b663e6e7894ace136b6f4653db4985
Related-bug: 1375348
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/64/125864/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock @mock.patch('time.sleep', return_value=None) @mock.patch.object(container_updater.ContainerUpdater, 'get_paths') @mock.patch('os.fork') def test_run_forever_with_path_exception(self, mock_os_fork, mock_get_paths, mock_time_sleep): e = OSError('permission_denied') mock_get_paths.side_effect = e cu = container_updater.ContainerUpdater({ 'devices': self.devices_dir, 'mount_check': 'false', 'swift_dir': self.testdir, 'interval': '1', 'concurrency': '1', 'node_timeout': '15', 'account_suppression_time': 0 }) cu.run_forever self.assertEqual(0, mock_os_fork.call_count) @mock.patch.object(container_updater.ContainerUpdater, 'get_paths') @mock.patch('time.sleep', return_value=None) @mock.patch.object(container_updater.ContainerUpdater, 'container_sweep') @mock.patch('os.fork', return_value=0) def test_run_forever_with_fork_exception(self, mock_os_fork, mock_container_sweep, mock_time_sleep, mock_get_paths): e = OSError('permission_denied') mock_container_sweep.side_effect = e mock_get_paths.return_value = '/tmp' cu = container_updater.ContainerUpdater({ 'devices': self.devices_dir, 'mount_check': 'false', 'swift_dir': self.testdir, 'interval': '1', 'concurrency': '1', 'node_timeout': '15', 'account_suppression_time': 0 }) self.assertRaises(SystemExit, cu.run_forever)

commit_message:
Add default_volume_type to cinder config

This allows the administrator of a cloud with multiple backends to
define which volume is the default when a user creats a volume without
specifying a volume type.

Change-Id: I1bb94dc1283e50645e4aece600acc52ae17db56b
Co-Authored-By: Craige McWhirter <craige.mcwhirter@anchor.com.au>
Closes-Bug: #1389292

deleted_lines: netapp_server_port = 80 (IntOpt) The TCP port to use for communication with the storage system or proxy server. Traditionally, port 80 is used for HTTP and port 443 is used for HTTPS; however, this value should be changed if an alternate port has been configured on the storage system or proxy server.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/12/133112/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: A work-around is described in :ref:`exclude-from-raid`.
deleted_lines: You can work around this issue as follows. This example is for a system that has three disks: sda, sdb, and sdc. Fuel will provision sda and sdb as RAID-1 for OpenStack but sdc will not be used as part of the RAID-1 array: #. Use the Fuel CLI to obtain provisioning data: :: fuel provisioning --env-id 1 --default -d #. Remove the drive which you do not want to be part of RAID: :: - size: 300 type: boot - file_system: ext2 mount: /boot name: Boot size: 200 type: raid #. Run deployment :: fuel provisioning --env-id 1 -u #. Confirm that your partition is not included in the RAID array: :: [root@node-2 ~]# cat /proc/mdstat Personalities : [raid1] md0 : active raid1 sda3[0] sdb3[1] 204736 blocks super 1.0 [2/2] [UU]

commit_message:
Fixes DOS issue in instance list ip filter

Converts the ip filtering to filter the list locally based
on the network info cache instead of making an extremely expensive
call over to nova network where it attempts to retrieve a list
of every instance in the system.

Change-Id: I455f6ab4acdecacc5152b11a183027f933dc4475
Closes-bug: #1358583
(cherry picked from commit 24c8cc53fd6a62fcad1287b2cdcf32d2ff0991d9)

commit_message:
libvirt: disk_info should be passed to _create_domain_and_network

In order to start LXC instances, disk_info should be passed
to _create_domain_and_network for it to determinine if the instance
has been started from an Image or a Volume.

Updating hard_reboot as well finish_migration
and finish_revert_migration

Change-Id: I9a43e1f919b554b56cd9eb688cd0ed3dec03c959
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/132912/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
scheduler: Remove assert on the exact number of weighers

Since the weighers code is by design pluggable, downstream packagers may have
added additional weigher classes, causing this assert to fail.

Rather than require downstream maintain a patch against this line, the
proposal is to remove it since the asserts after it are sufficient.

Change-Id: I13765fae188af92a2e729dcd14caf981db01acb4

commit_message:
Fix instance_usage_audit_log test to use admin context

Nova V2 API 'os-instance_usage_audit_log' is for admin only
and Nova policy.json has rule for the same But
test_instance_usage_audit_log tests this API as non admin.

This patch fix test_instance_usage_audit_log test to use admin
context.

Also adding some more tests to verify this API with non-admin context.

commit_message:
object: update instance numa object to handle pagesize

Work-item: Enhance libvirt driver to report available
           large pages per NUMA node in the host state data

Partial-Implement: blueprint virt-driver-large-pages
Change-Id: I392bdc45aa3b6b169c1d1bfdada624a16c77c91c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/82/129682/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mempages_0_1 = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMAPages() mempages_0_1.size = 4 mempages_0_1.total = 298376 mempages_0_2 = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMAPages() mempages_0_2.size = 2048 mempages_0_2.total = 0 cell_0.mempages = [mempages_0_1, mempages_0_2] mempages_1_1 = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMAPages() mempages_1_1.size = 4 mempages_1_1.total = 938462 mempages_1_2 = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMAPages() mempages_1_2.size = 2048 mempages_1_2.total = 0 cell_1.mempages = [mempages_1_1, mempages_1_2] def test_get_host_hugepages_topology(self): conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) conn._conn.getLibVersion = mock.MagicMock(return_value=1002009) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() expected_topo_dict = {'cells': [ {0: { 2048: {'total': 0, 'used': 0}, 4: {'total': 298376, 'used': 0}}}, {1: { 2048: {'total': 0, 'used': 0}, 4: {'total': 938462, 'used': 0}}}]} with mock.patch.object( conn, '_get_host_capabilities', return_value=caps): got_topo = conn._get_host_hugepages_topology() got_topo_dict = got_topo._to_dict() self.assertThat( expected_topo_dict, matchers.DictMatches(got_topo_dict)) def test_get_host_hugepages_topology_empty(self): conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) conn._conn.getLibVersion = mock.MagicMock(return_value=1002009) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.topology = None with mock.patch.object( conn, '_get_host_capabilities', return_value=caps): self.assertIsNone(conn._get_host_hugepages_topology()) def test_get_host_hugepages_topology_not_supported(self): conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) conn._conn.getLibVersion = mock.MagicMock(return_value=1002006) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() with mock.patch.object( conn, '_get_host_capabilities', return_value=caps): self.assertIsNone(conn._get_host_hugepages_topology())

commit_message:
hardware: make cell instance topology to handle memory pages

Updates VirtNUMATopologyCellInstance to take into account
account pagesize information

Work-Item: Enhance libvirt driver to report available
           large pages per NUMA node in the host state data

Partial-Implement: blueprint virt-driver-large-pages
Change-Id: Ib8772bff16f6ba58a6266a2ef40b9d81b1d7f00a

added_lines: def __init__(self, id, cpuset, memory, mempages=(), cpu_usage=0, memory_usage=0, mempages_usage=()): :param mempages: set of (size, avail) memory pages measured in KiB :param mempages_usage: set of (size, used) memory pages measured in KiB id, cpuset, memory, mempages) self.mempages_usage = mempages_usage usage = dict(self.mempages_usage) [data_dict['mempages'][str(s)].setdefault('used', usage.get(int(s), 0)) for s, u in six.iteritems(data_dict['mempages'])] mempages = set((int(k), v.get('total', 0)) for k, v in six.iteritems( data_dict.get('mempages', {}))) mempages_usage = set((int(k), v.get('used', 0)) for k, v in six.iteritems( data_dict.get('mempages', {}))) return cls(cell_id, cpuset, memory, mempages, cpu_usage, memory_usage, mempages_usage) mempages_usage = hostcell.mempages_usage if hasattr(instancecell, 'mempages'): for size in hostcell.mempages_usage: mempages_usage[size] = max(0, ( mempages_usage[size] + sign * instancecell.mempages[size])) id=hostcell.id, cpuset=hostcell.cpuset, memory=hostcell.memory, cpu_usage=max(0, cpu_usage), memory_usage=max(0, memory_usage), mempages_usage=mempages_usage)

commit_message:
hardware: introduce VirtNUMATopologyCellInstance

Introduces a new class VirtNUMATopologyCellInstance which extends
VirtNUMATopologyCell used to handle cells of VirtNUMAInstanceTopology
Also this commit make VirtNUMATopologyCell an abstract class.

Work-item: Enhance libvirt driver to report available
           large pages per NUMA node in the host state data

Change-Id: Icac19c17caec98ae31c039a2b22a7c1de546d9a2
Partial-Implement: blueprint virt-driver-large-pages

commit_message:
First set of functional tests for orders

Adding the first set of functional tests for orders, plus supporting
changes to models and additional utility functions in test.utils.

Change-Id: I0f461b23d3256c3b158cedc414bb0cc6b087ff7e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/61/130961/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from datetime import datetime, timedeltafrom os import path def get_tomorrow_timestamp(): tomorrow = (datetime.today() + timedelta(days=1)) return tomorrow.isoformat() def string_to_datetime(datetimestring, date_formats=None): date_formats = date_formats or [ '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f', '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%fZ', '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f', "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ", "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S"] for dateformat in date_formats: try: return datetime.strptime(datetimestring, dateformat) except ValueError: continue else: raise def get_id_from_ref(ref): """Returns id from reference.""" ref_id = None if ref is not None and len(ref) > 0: ref_id = path.split(ref)[1] return ref_id

commit_message:
Nova BP for trusted lcoation control

Change-Id: If6ff6caf27b138122d722e53ff07f9782d507370
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/132592/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **Hardware assisted Geo and Asset Tagging** URL of your launchpad blueprint: link: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-trusted-geo-asset-tag This blueprint details how geo and asset tagging can be incorporated and taken advantage of in OpenStack clouds to provide location and boundary control of workloads/OpenStack images. With Geo/Asset Tags, you can enforce policies to control placement, migration or bursting of workloads to trusted systems in specific geographical locations or boundaries, provide visibility and compliance of your workload policies to ensure tenants that of its compliance to Trust and location policies. Extensions from this solution enable associating geo and asset tags with hardware at provision time. Intel Trusted Execution Environment (TXT) and other measured launch environments (MLEs) facilitate measurement of provision time information into the Trusted Platform Module (TPM). Remote attestation services can then be used to ascertain that provision time meta-data have not been tampered. Geo and Asset tagging builds on the Trusted Compute Pools feature, covered in TrustedComputingPools **Problem description** While the cloud enables workloads and data to reside anywhere, users may be constrained to run their workloads and save their data in certain geographies due to regulatory requirements. This solution will extend to include trusting the location and boundary of the hardware resources, extending the current functionality of trusting the integrality of the compute platform to be free of malware and rootkits. **Use Cases** *Use case 1* – The end-user can enforce VM/Images policies to control placement, migration or bursting of workloads to trusted systems within specific geographical locations or boundaries **Project Priority** Does this blueprint fit under one of the ref `kilo-priorities`? If so which one and how **Proposed change** Creating a new nova-scheduler filter which supports both trust and geo-tag filters. Update the image update portal in horizon to display geo-tags created by the user in the attestation server and add the ability to provision tags to an image Include trust and geo location visibility in the horizon dashboard for hypervisors, images and instances pages Geo and asset tag solution: To create and add Geo-Location/Asset-tag Policies to VM Image Properties in Open Stack The following changes have been made to the Images page under the Admin tab. * Display of Trust Policies assigned to each Image. #. Trust Policies can be created and edited in the Create Image tab and Edit function for each Image. #. Trust Policies, for now, include Platform Integrity and Location and in the future will include VM Integrity. * Trust Policies and related information as stored as Image properties in the glance database. * If Trust Policy for Location is selected, Platform Integrity is automatically selected. * When selecting the Location Trust; user will have option to create policy of one or more of the 5 Key name and value pairs. * 5 key names include: Country, State, City. Region and Classification. * Acceptable values for each Key Name will need to be selected from a drop down list. The acceptable values are fetched from the Remote Attestation Solution *Asset/Location Filter in Scheduler to orchestrate and control Trust Policies.* * When a user selects an image to be launched for an instance, the scheduler retrieves the ‘Trust Policy’ for the Glance database * Scheduler iterates through the available host and fetches the SAML assertion from the ‘Remote Attestation Service’ using Restful API. * SAML Assertion is parsed to determine match to the ‘Trust Policy’ and once these iterations are completed, scheduler will complete the remaining filter operation and then picks the best ranked host to launch the instance. *Trust Visibility within OpenStack Horizon* * Horizon dashboards have been updated to display Trust Status in 2 dashboards under the Admin Tab – Hypervisor and Instances * The Hypervisor dashboard displays trust status of all Policies (Platform and Location). In addition, when you mouse over the location icon it will show the Asset/Geo tag provisioned in the Hardware of the host. * Every time the Hypervisor dashboard is loaded, ‘Trust Status’ is updated by fetching the SAML assertion from the ‘Remote Attestation Service’ using Restful API. * The Instance dashboard displays trust status of all Policies (Platform and Location). In addition, when you mouse over the location icon it will show the Location/ Tag Policy applied. * if there are no Trust policies associated to the image the Instance is using, then the Trust Status for that instance will be empty. * Trusted Icons for each policy will be displayed in green and untrusted in Red *Files added or modified:* New file: * asset_tag_filter.py Modified files: * nova.conf [trusted_computing] attestation_server= attestation_port= attestation_auth_blob= asset_tag_server= attestation_api_url= attestation_server_ca_file= asset_tag_server_url= asset_tag_server_port= asset_tag_server_auth_blob= *Image attributes changes* Image attributes are stored in the Glance DB id | image_id | name | value 47 | 934bf0cd-82ab-4edb-b6ff-1407d99c0386 | trust | true **Data model impact** N/A **REST API impact** Here is the format that we are expecting with the glance image –create command glance image-create --name cirros --disk-format qcow2 --min-disk 10 --min-ram 1024 --file cirros-0.3.1-x86_64-disk.img --property trust=true --property tags="{'country': 'US', 'state': 'CA'}}" --container-format bare **Security impact** N/A **Notifications impact** N/A **Other end user impact** * Trust status and Geo-location policies are now visible in the horizon dashboard * 4 image files are added that represent geo-location, platform trusted, platform un-trusted and platform trusted with geo-location policy * The user will be able to add Geo-Location/Asset-tag Policies to VM Image Properties in horizon **Performance Impact** We don’t have a local cache at this point. When a user launches an instance, the new trust filter checks the geo Tags of each of the compute nodes in sequential order. (No local cache is maintained). So, the instance creation wait time is directly proportional to the number of compute nodes available in the Cloud. **Other deployer impact** Modifications required after the user deploys and configured OpenStack *Configuration changes for Nova.conf* [trusted_computing] attestation_server = attestation_port = attestation_auth_blob = asset_tag_server = attestation_api_url= attestation_server_ca_file = asset_tag_server_url = **Developer impact** N/A **Implementation** Assignee(s) Naresh Gadepalli Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> **Work Items** **Work Items** N/A **Dependencies** The end user will need of attestation authority appliance for this new nova filter to work. If the feature does not exist – instances would not launch is trust policy is set to true, If false, instances would launch and our new trust filter would not play a role in the decision. **Testing** Intel will test end-end functionality internally at our test facility. We will provide all the test cases and test results along with code submissions. Others who want to download and test can access Attestation server appliance by contacting Intel: jwheeler@intel.com **Documentation Impact** Use case, Code, deployment and test case documentation will provided at a later date. **References** http://www.Intel.com/txt

commit_message:
WIP - Conductor remotely claim resource

Currently the conductor has to rpc to the compute node for prep_resize
because the resource claim can't be achieved remotely.

With the changes of the resource remote claim, update the conductor
to use it.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint persistent-resource-claim

Change-Id: Ib096b3fe4eae71c3ce28f18d587ea3c5e917eaab

commit_message:
Change resource tracker for remote claim

Change the resource tracker to support remote claim. We keep the
original context-based return value, and add a new interface to claim
and abort claim.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint persistent-resource-claim

Change-Id: Ib198dba67abdaedc4157fdb4edd7eba9b8d46c51

commit_message:
Keep claim information in resource tracker

Currently in resource claim, the resource tracker return the claim
as context manager, but does not keep any claim information.

This patch change the resource tracker to keep the resource claim
locally in memory and track the resource usage base on the claim.

The initial resource claim information is collected when
update_available_resources() is invoked the first time.

The overall audit process is still based on instance and migration, we
can update it in future to be based purely on claim.

Implements: blueprint persistent-resource-claim

Change-Id: I265f87db9c9197e868e5b4d047f578de9b9b8625

commit_message:
Add persistent claims support

An api is provided to persist claims to storage, and provides
a driver implementation to persist the claims information in local
sqlite DB.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint persistent-resource-claim

Change-Id: I779ebe191d64e3bb5f99541aa360f47a0c2e937e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/108555/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Intel Corporation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import shutil import sqlite3 import tempfile import mock from oslo.config import cfg from nova.compute import claims_api from nova.openstack.common import timeutils from nova import exception from nova import test CONF = cfg.CONF def fake_claim(**updates): claim_dict = { 'host': 'h1', 'node': 'n1', 'instance_uuid': 'fake-uuid', 'vcpus': 1, 'memory_mb': 256, 'disk_gb': 20, 'pci_devices': "", 'instance_type_id': 2, 'created_at': timeutils.utcnow(), } if updates: claim_dict.update(updates) return claim_dict class PersistClaimSqliteTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(PersistClaimSqliteTestCase, self).setUp() self.tempdir = tempfile.mkdtemp() self.dbfile = os.path.join(self.tempdir, 'claim.db') CONF.set_override('claim_sqlite', self.dbfile) self.addCleanup(self.removeDB) def removeDB(self): shutil.rmtree(self.tempdir) def test_new_scratch(self): claims = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() self.assertFalse(claims.populated) version = claims._get_db_version() self.assertEqual(version['version'] , '1.0') def _change_version(self, new_version): conn = sqlite3.connect(self.dbfile) conn.execute("update versions set version=? where table_name=? ", (new_version, 'claims')) conn.commit() conn.close() def test_version_newer(self): claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() self._change_version("1.1") self.assertRaises(exception.PersistentClaimVersionMismatch, claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite) @mock.patch("nova.compute.claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite._update_claims") def test_version_update(self, mock_update): claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() self._change_version("0.9") claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() mock_update.assert_called_with_once_with("0.9") def test_save(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() claim = fake_claim() claim_api.save(claim) claim_api.finish_recreate() claims = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite().get_all_claims('h1', 'n1') self.assertEqual(len(claims), 1) self.assertEqual(claims[0]['id'], 1) self.assertEqual(claims[0]['host'], 'h1') def test_drop(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() claim = fake_claim() claim_api.save(claim) claim_api.finish_recreate() claims = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite().get_all_claims('h1', 'n1') self.assertEqual(len(claims), 1) claim_api.drop(claims[0]['id']) claims = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite().get_all_claims('h1', 'n1') self.assertEqual(len(claims), 0) def test_finish_recreate(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() self.assertRaises(exception.PersistentClaimUnPopulated, claim_api.get_all_claims) claim_api.finish_recreate() claims = claim_api.get_all_claims('h1', 'n1') self.assertEqual(len(claims), 0) def test_get_all_claims(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() claim = fake_claim() claim_api.save(claim) claim_1 = fake_claim(instance_uuid='fake_uuid_1', vcpus=2) claim_api.save(claim_1) claim_api.finish_recreate() claims = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite().get_all_claims('h1', 'n1') self.assertEqual(len(claims), 2) self.assertEqual(set([claims[0]['vcpus'], claims[1]['vcpus']]), set([1, 2])) def test_get_claim_by_id(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() claim = fake_claim() claim_id = claim_api.save(claim) claim_api.finish_recreate() fetch_claim = claim_api.get_claim_by_id('h1', 'n1', claim_id) self.assertEqual(fetch_claim['id'], claim_id) self.assertEqual(fetch_claim['vcpus'], claim['vcpus']) def test_get_claim_by_id_fail(self): claim_api = claims_api.PersistClaimSqlite() claim = fake_claim() claim_api.save(claim) claim_api.finish_recreate() fetch_claim = claim_api.get_claim_by_id('h1', 'n1', 2) self.assertEqual(fetch_claim, None)

subject: Replace pci_stat's extra_info with phys_function
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-25 00:43:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b0265c0e1e8f00266a3e5e60dfb579dda6ad6c86', 'message': 'Remove the extra_info from pci_stats pool_keys

Currently the pci_stats is created based on
(vendor_id, product_id, extra_info), this is not good
because:

a) It keeps the pci_stats as dict of dict, i.e. a value in the
dict can be a dict still, this is complex for object,
b) extra_info would combine several PCI device properties as planned,
we should abstract the pci_stats based on device properties, instead
of the overall extra_info.

This patch removes the extra_info from the pool_keys and provides a
configuration item, so that user can specify any pci device property
contained in the extra_info.

This should have no upgrade issue because the pci_stats is created on
compute node and consumed by scheduler node. Between the upgrade of
scheduler node and compute nodes, PCI device allocation request may fail,
but that failure is temp and will be back as soon as any compute node is
upgraded.

Change-Id: I9f8d89787480132c34daf4c6d69e358354ec3621
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-16 21:38:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6ca3f9011d8af476caa3ce457faf0ecf9a464208', 'message': 'Remove the extra_info from pci_stats pool_keys

This patch removes the extra_info from the pool_keys and provides a

This should have no upgrade issue because the pci_stats is created on

Change-Id: I9f8d89787480132c34daf4c6d69e358354ec3621
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-06-19 22:06:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b52d20f3100a630409f396b9c32b945bf4a1de6b', 'message': 'Change the pci_stats to support compute node object

Change compute node object to include pci_stats. The pci_stats field is list
of dicts, the value in the dict item is a string.

However, currently the pci_stats include the extra_info, which itself is
a dict. Thus the extra_info in the pci_stats is changed to be phys_function,
which is the only item in the extra_specs now. The corresponding pci_alias
configuration should be changed to use phys_function.

This should have no upgrade issue because the pci_stats is created on
compute node and consumed by scheduler node. Between the upgrade of
scheduler node and compute nodes, PCI device allocation request may fail,
but that failure is temp and will be back as soon as compute node is
upgraded.

Implements: blueprint make-resource-tracker-use-objects

Change-Id: I9f8d89787480132c34daf4c6d69e358354ec3621
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2014-06-19 23:47:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e5a6682f5bf99b5ee6e38f6308534a40610a4b36', 'message': 'Change the pci_stats to support compute node object

Change compute node object to include pci_stats. The pci_stats field is list
of dicts, the value in the dict item is a string.

However, currently the pci_stats include the extra_info, which itself is
a dict. Thus the extra_info in the pci_stats is changed to be phys_function,
which is the only item in the extra_specs now. The corresponding pci_alias
configuration should be changed to use phys_function.

This should have no upgrade issue because the pci_stats is created on
compute node and consumed by scheduler node. Between the upgrade of
scheduler node and compute nodes, PCI device allocation request may fail,
but that failure is temp and will be back as soon as compute node is
upgraded.

Implements: blueprint make-resource-tracker-use-objects

DocImpact

Change-Id: I9f8d89787480132c34daf4c6d69e358354ec3621

commit_message:
Replace pci_stat's extra_info with phys_function

Currently the pci_stats include the extra_info, which is
a dict, thus it's difficult to change pci_stats as object.
Change it to be phys_function, which is the only item
in the extra_info now. The corresponding pci_alias
configuration should be changed to use phys_function.

This should have no upgrade issue because the pci_stats is created by
compute node and consumed by scheduler node. Between the upgrade of
scheduler node and compute nodes, PCI device allocation request may fail,
but that failure is temp and will be back as soon as compute node is
upgraded.

Implements: blueprint make-resource-tracker-use-objects

Change-Id: I9f8d89787480132c34daf4c6d69e358354ec3621
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/76053/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_dev_property(dev_obj, dev_prop): """ Get PCI device property. A PCI device property may be kept in extra_info like phys_function. """ intrinsic_prop = ['vendor_id', 'product_id', 'dev_type', 'label'] if dev_prop in intrinsic_prop: return dev_obj.get(dev_prop) else: return dev_obj.extra_info.get(dev_prop)

commit_message:
The last round of secrets functional tests

This is the last round for functional tests for secrets.
This includes all data driven and paging functional tests.
The tests are tagged for negative or positive tests to
make for faster running or logical test runs for groups.
Removed paging tests due to timing issues with loops.
The tests cannot be run in parallel so will have to be
completed separately.

Change-Id: I532ebf41643ff871ff1f2d8aa476cf6e6655baa6

test_secret_create_defaults_valid_mode(self, mode): """Covers cases of creating a secret with invalid bit lengths.""" test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) overrides = {"mode": mode} test_model.override_values(**overrides) resp, secret_ref = self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 201) @utils.parameterized_dataset({ 'text_content_type_none_encoding': { 'payload_content_type': 'text/plain', 'payload_content_encoding': None}, 'utf8_text_content_type_none_encoding': { 'payload_content_type': 'text/plain; charset=utf-8', 'payload_content_encoding': None}, 'no_space_utf8_text_content_type_none_encoding': { 'payload_content_type': 'text/plain;charset=utf-8', 'payload_content_encoding': None}, 'octet_content_type_base64_encoding': { 'payload_content_type': 'application/octet-stream', 'payload_content_encoding': 'base64'} # Removing for Bug #1252873 # 'space_charset_utf8_text_content_type_none_encoding': { # 'payload_content_type': 'text/plain; charset=utf-8 ', # 'payload_content_encoding': None}, # # 'caps_text_content_type_and_encoding': { # 'payload_content_type': 'TEXT/plain', # 'payload_content_encoding': None}, # # 'trailing_space_text_content_type_none_encoding': { # 'payload_content_type': 'text/plain ', # 'payload_content_encoding': None}, }) @testcase.attr('positive', 'ddtest') def test_secret_create_defaults_normalize(self, **kwargs): """Covers creating secret with various valid combinations of content types and encodings. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) test_model.override_values(**kwargs) payload_content_encoding = test_model.payload_content_encoding resp, secret_ref = self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 201) get_resp = self.behaviors.get_secret( secret_ref, payload_content_type=test_model.payload_content_type, payload_content_encoding=payload_content_encoding) if payload_content_encoding == 'base64': self.assertIn(test_model.payload, binascii.b2a_base64(get_resp.content)) else: self.assertIn(test_model.payload, get_resp.content) class SecretsPaging(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(SecretsPaging, self).setUp() self.behaviors = secret_behaviors.SecretBehaviors(self.client) def tearDown(self): self.behaviors.delete_all_created_secrets() super(SecretsPaging, self).tearDown() @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_limit_and_offset(self): """Covers testing paging limit and offset attributes when getting secrets. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) # First set of secrets resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=10, offset=0) secrets = secrets # Second set of secrets resp, secrets2, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=10, offset=10) secrets2 = secrets2 duplicates = [entity for entity in secrets if entity in secrets2] self.assertEqual(len(duplicates), 0) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_default_find_single_created_secret(self): """Covers case where when you attempt to retrieve a list of secrets, if the limit is set higher than 8, the next attribute in the response is not available. - Reported in Barbican GitHub Issue #81 """ limit = 10 offset = 0 test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) overrides = {'name': 'Find This Key'} test_model.override_values(**overrides) resp, secret_ref = self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 201) while True: names = [] resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=limit, offset=offset) for secret in secrets: names.append(secret.name) if test_model.name in names or next_ref is None: break else: limit, offset = utils.get_limit_and_offset_from_ref(next_ref) self.assertIn(test_model.name, names) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_limit(self): """Covers listing secrets with limit attribute from limits of 2 to 25. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) for limit in range(2, 25): resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=limit, offset=0) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertEqual(len(secrets), limit) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_max_limit(self): """Covers case of listing secrets with a limit more than the current maximum of 100. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 102): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=101, offset=0) self.assertEqual(len(secrets), 100) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_next_option(self): """Covers getting a list of secrets and using the next reference. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 150): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) # First set of secrets resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=15, offset=115) self.assertIsNotNone(next_ref) limit, offset = utils.get_limit_and_offset_from_ref(next_ref) # Next set of secrets resp, secrets2, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit, offset) duplicates = [entity for entity in secrets if entity in secrets2] self.assertEqual(len(duplicates), 0) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_offset(self): """Covers listing secrets with offset attribute from offsets of 2 to 25. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) # Covers offsets between 1 and 25 for offset in range(1, 24): resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=2, offset=offset) previous_secrets = secrets self.assertIsNotNone(previous_secrets) resp, secrets2, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=2, offset=offset + 2) current_secrets = secrets2 duplicates = [entity for entity in secrets if previous_secrets in current_secrets] self.assertEqual(len(duplicates), 0) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secrets_get_defaults_paging_previous_option(self): """Covers getting a list of secrets and using the previous reference. """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) # First set of secrets resp, secrets, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=5, offset=20) previous_secrets = secrets limit, offset = utils.get_limit_and_offset_from_ref(prev_ref) # Previous set of secrets resp, secrets2, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit=limit, offset=offset) current_secrets = secrets2 duplicates = [entity for entity in secrets if previous_secrets in current_secrets] self.assertEqual(len(duplicates), 0) @testcase.attr('positive') def test_secret_get_defaults_paging_w_invalid_parameters(self): """Covers listing secrets with invalid limit and offset parameters. - Reported in Barbican GitHub Issue #171 """ test_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**secret_create_defaults_data) for x in range(1, 31): self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) resp, secret_ref, next_ref, prev_ref = self.behaviors.get_secrets( limit='not-an-int', offset='not-an-int') self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200)

commit_message:
Record actions performed as root via sudo

This change enables sudo command logging for devstack installation time only,
using sudo built in debug flags.
Every 'sudo' command is now logged in below format to /var/log/sudo_debug.
Format example:
    Nov  4 18:39:21 sudo[1850] executed /bin/chmod, pid 1851
    Nov  4 18:39:21 sudo[1851] exec /bin/chmod [chmod 0755 /opt/stack]

This can help troubleshoot and understand how devstack works and what it does.

Change-Id: Ib2dba924e63c8df896d9967e71f3c9c291493bbd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/12/132712/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Enable logging for sudo TEMPFILE=$(mktemp) echo 'Debug sudo /var/log/sudo_debug exec@info' > $TEMPFILE chmod 0440 $TEMPFILE sudo chown root:root $TEMPFILE sudo mv $TEMPFILE /etc/sudo.conf unset TEMPFILE unset TEMPFILE

subject: Upgrade to avoid vulnerable requests-kerberos versions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-04 18:56:16.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/37404dc3ae56ab021da220b38242bba6fc44c47d', 'message': 'Upgrade to avoid vulnerable requests-kerberos versions

All versions of requests-kerberos prior to 0.6 do not properly handle
mutual authentication. In short this means that the server was never
properly verified and a client could potentially send sensitive data to
an untrusted server.

Change-Id: I1e9a3b1af15e69ae5c155a146638774cf472ef33
'}]
commit_message:
Upgrade to avoid vulnerable requests-kerberos versions

All versions of requests-kerberos prior to 0.6 do not properly handle
mutual authentication. In short this means that the server was never
properly verified and a client could potentially send sensitive data to
an untrusted server.

Change-Id: I1e9a3b1af15e69ae5c155a146638774cf472ef33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/11/132711/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: requests-kerberos>=0.6 # MIT

This is a work-in-progress.

To see the pager in action, the # items per table > # Item Per Page (set via Settings > Items Per Page)

Notes:
1. using jquery.tablesorter.pager.js, a small ext of tablesorter plugin we are currently using to sort
downloaded from here: http://tablesorter.com/addons/pager/jquery.tablesorter.pager.js
2. Tables with marker API supported pagination (i.e. Admin > Instances, Admin > Projects) still function the same way as before
3. Items Per Page value in dropdown is set via Settings Page

*Have to hook filter search to work with the pager.

This will address bugs: #1212174, #1279498, #1282987, #1263142

Change-Id: Iabc3e998c3bdbc2fd02ee7e5e93bfeea195ac5f2

"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2014-08-11 16:46:40.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/static/dashboard/scss/horizon.scss', 'horizon/tables/base.py', 'horizon/templates/horizon/_scripts.html', 'horizon/templates/horizon/common/_data_table.html', 'horizon/static/horizon/js/horizon.tables.js', 'horizon/static/horizon/lib/jquery/jquery.tablesorter.pager.js'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/bc3a2a0bf74a804ed47be582dbadb316133864e3', 'message': "fallback client-side pagination, sorting across pages

Client-side pagination will only work for tables where the API
doesn't support pagination.

Tables with marker API supported pagination (e.g Admin > Instance,
Admin > Project) *still* function the same way as before.  This patch
provides a fallback/bridge feature gap for tables that don't have api
support, it is not *replacing* anything.

To see the pager in action, the # items per table > # Item Per Page
(set via Settings)

Notes:
1. uses jquery.tablesorter.pager.js, an ext of tablesorter plugin
we are currently using to sort downloaded from here:
http://mottie.github.io/tablesorter/addons/pager/jquery.tablesorter.pager.js

Implements: blueprint client-side-pagination

commit_message:
fallback client-side pagination, sorting across pages

Client-side pagination will only work for tables where the API
doesn't support pagination.

Tables with marker API supported pagination (e.g Admin > Instance,
Admin > Project) *still* function the same way as before.  This patch
provides a fallback/bridge feature gap for tables that don't have api
support, it is not *replacing* anything.

To see the pager in action, the # items per table > # Item Per Page
(set via Settings)

Notes:
1. uses jquery.tablesorter.pager.js, an ext of tablesorter plugin
we are currently using to sort downloaded from here:
http://mottie.github.io/tablesorter/addons/pager/jquery.tablesorter.pager.js
(included in static file package we plan to use in future - xstatic - so
no overhead)
2. This will help provide consistency.
3. Takes the Items Per Page value from Settings
4. Filter search works with the pager as well

Partial-Bug: #1263142

Change-Id: Iabc3e998c3bdbc2fd02ee7e5e93bfeea195ac5f2
Implements: blueprint client-side-pagination

Added smoke tests for orders

Added smoke tests for orders as well as updates to orders
models and behaviors.

Change-Id: I82be185f7a99ff8b7d10d5b39f3190e7671d3df1

added_lines: """ Copyright 2014 Rackspace Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. """ from functionaltests.api.v1.behaviors import base_behaviors from functionaltests.api.v1.models import order_models class OrderBehaviors(base_behaviors.BaseBehaviors): def create_order(self, model, extra_headers=None): """Create an order from the data in the model. :param model: The data used to create the order :param extra_headers: Optional HTTP headers to add to the request :return: The create response and href for the order """ # create the order resp = self.client.post('orders', request_model=model, extra_headers=extra_headers) returned_data = resp.json() order_ref = returned_data.get('order_ref') # remember this order for our housekeeping cleanup if order_ref: self.created_entities.append(order_ref) return resp, order_ref def get_order(self, order_ref, extra_headers=None): """Get an order from an href. :param order_ref: The href for an order :param extra_headers: Optional HTTP headers to add to the request :return: The response from the get """ return self.client.get(order_ref, response_model_type=order_models.OrderModel, extra_headers=extra_headers) def get_orders(self, limit=10, offset=0, extra_headers=None): """Get a list of orders. :param limit: limits number of returned orders (default 10) :param offset: represents how many records to skip before retrieving the list (default 0) :param extra_headers: Optional HTTP headers to add to the request :return the response, a list of orders and the next/pref hrefs """ resp = self.client.get('orders', params={'limit': limit, 'offset': offset}, extra_headers=extra_headers) orders_list = resp.json() orders, next_ref, prev_ref = self.client.get_list_of_models( orders_list, order_models.OrderModel) return resp, orders, next_ref, prev_ref def delete_order(self, order_ref, extra_headers=None, expected_fail=False): """Delete an order. :param order_ref: HATEOS ref of the order to be deleted :param extra_headers: Optional HTTP headers to add to the request :param expected_fail: Flag telling the delete whether or not this operation is expected to fail (ie coming from a negative test). We need this to determine whether or not this delete should also remove an entity from our internal list for housekeeping. :return A request response object """ resp = self.client.delete(order_ref, extra_headers=extra_headers) if (not expected_fail): self.created_entities.remove(order_ref) return resp def delete_all_created_orders(self): """Delete all of the orders that we have created.""" orders_to_delete = [order for order in self.created_entities] for order_ref in orders_to_delete: self.delete_order(order_ref)

corresponding models and behaviors.
